journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Near-time-optimal tracking controller design for an automotive electromechanical brake

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Melbourne, Melbourne, Victoria 3010, Australia. email: c.lee33@pgrad.unimelb.edu.au

abstract.p: A state-constrained, robust near-time-optimal clamp force tracking controller for an automotive electromechanical brake is presented. The proposed hybrid control structure consists of two switching control laws that handle tracking of rate-bounded references in the presence of state constraints. The responsive tracking utilizes an approximated time-optimal switching curve as a sliding manifold, while state constraints are handled by a linearizing–stabilizing feedback controller. The hybrid controller is proven to asymptotically track the reference in the presence of unknown but bounded time-varying disturbances and modelling errors. Implementation and validation of the proposed controller on a prototype electromechanical brake enables favourable performance comparisons with existing servo control architectures to be obtained.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The advent of drive-by-wire in the automotive domain has been led by throttle-by-wire systems, with demonstrated success across a host of different vehicle platforms. Brake-by-wire systems are the next stage along the drive-by-wire trajectory, and are facilitated by electromechanical brakes (EMBs), such as the prototype pictured in Fig. 1. The EMB offers several advantages over its hydraulic counterparts including reduced environmental impact, improved manufacturability through plug-and-play capability, improved flexibility in design, and integration particularly with respect to electric vehicles, and significantly higher closed-loop bandwidths with respect to hydraulic systems. Naturally however, full realization of the benefits of these closed-loop bandwidths depends on the performance and robustness of the EMB control algorithm.

caption.p: A prototype electromechanical brake used in this work

sec.p: The EMB control problem dealt with in this paper is at the servo-control level, taking into account the time-varying reference tracking invoked by higher-level functionality such as anti-lock braking systems (ABS). To ensure a good tracking performance, the servo must consider non-linear characteristics such as actuator saturation, friction, and non-linear stiffness.

Founded on a standard motion control architecture, earlier attempts at EMB servo control used a proportional–integral (PI) controller with cascaded force, motor velocity, and motor current control-loop architecture, and ignored system non-linearities [1, 2]. Non-linear friction compensation was considered in reference [3], where an inverse-model controller was proposed. Since the controller was designed as the direct inverse of the model, it was not robust to modelling error, therefore yielding steady-state errors.

Building on reference [2], Line et al. [4] integrated the feedback linearization of the non-linear stiffness and friction with the cascaded PI controller, and proposed this controller as the baseline EMB controller. Due to non-linear stiffness, a set of fixed gains could not yield consistent performance over the entire operating range. This impediment was addressed in reference [5] by scheduling the proportional gain of the force loop according to the clamp force reference.

Additional improvements to the cascaded PI controller structure were achieved through the introduction of a linear unconstrained model predictive controller (MPC) [4]. Nevertheless, input and state constraints were handled in an ad hoc way. Furthermore, the control available for the MPC was reduced due to the additional torque demanded for feedback linearization.

To avoid posing feedback linearization and controller design as different subproblems, while considering the input and state constraints explicitly, a holistic approach based on non-linear MPC design was proposed in reference [6]. The feedback gains were precomputed offline and implemented using a lookup table. While this controller yielded a faster response than previous attempts, it was found that the storage requirement of the gains was prohibitive under current and near-term hardware limits. This motivates a high-performance reference-tracking controller with reduced storage requirements.

The notion of high performance considered here refers to the time-optimality of the tracking responses. A fast EMB tracking response is important, especially during safety-critical operations such as ABS. Henceforth, time-optimality is a natural EMB control performance metric. Additionally, the controller must be robust to modelling errors and disturbance.

Some pioneering theoretical work on the time-optimal (TO) control problem can be traced back to applications of Pontryagin’s maximum principle [7]. TO control is also known as bang–bang control, as the control switches between the two extremes at some specific switching instances in the state space [8]. While this solution is optimal in the ideal case, its performance is sensitive to modelling errors [9]. The resulting chatter leads to vibration, excessive heat lost in power electronics, and wear in mechanical components – all clearly undesirable in a braking application.

In an effort to improve the robustness of the TO controller, the proximate time-optimal servomechanism (PTOS) was proposed in reference [10], where the regulation of a linear double integrator plant was considered. This was extended to the third-order system [11], and subsequent extensions and implementation on a hard disk drive were summarized in reference [12].

Zhou et al. [13] argued that PTOS performance, especially for the short stroke seeking in hard disk drives, can be improved by approximating the switching instances using a third-order polynomial of velocity. This approach was also extended to the discrete case in reference [14].

Based on a different control law in the vicinity of the switching, near-time-optimal control (NTOC) was suggested in reference [15] for the double-integrator regulation problem. Extension to a general non-linear second-order system was proposed in reference [16] with application in robotics. However, state constraints and reference tracking were not considered in this approach.

Furthermore, Singh and Vadali [17] suggested using frequency domain approach to analyse and design a robust TO control for linear, multi-order mechanical systems, while You and Lee [18] incorporated a combination of bang–bang principle, singular control, and sliding-mode control to attain a robust TO control for non-linear second-order systems.

Albeit that much work has been done in the area of robust TO control, due to the absence of state constraints or plant non-linearity, neither of the methods already mentioned are well suited to the EMB control problem. This motivates the development of a robust TO tracking controller that considers the specific requirements of an EMB.

In this paper, NTOC [15] is extended to handle reference tracking and state constraints. The proposed control structure is implemented and experimentally validated on a prototype EMB. For comparison, a traditional baseline cascaded PI controller is used to set baseline performance.

sec.title: 2 Near-Time-Optimal Tracking Control Design
sec.p: In order to preserve generality, the theory in this section is developed for a class of control-affine second-order non-linear systems that captures many motion control problems, including the EMB. In the initial derivation, disturbances due to modelling error are neglected, while modifications to the derived results due to bounded disturbances are considered in the sequel.
The following definitions of the signum and saturation functions will be used in this section

sec.title: 2.1 Controller design
sec.p: Consider the following description of a class of second-order non-linear systems. Without the loss of generality, the input u is normalized to unity, that is u∈[−1,1]
where x=(x1,x2)∈X⊂ℜ2, u∈U⊂ℜ, U is compact, f:X→ℜ2 with f(0)=0 and b>0. The state x2 is constrained to |x2|≤x2max.
In addition, the available control authority is strictly greater than |f(.)| over the whole operating range, and the minimum of the difference is denoted by ap.
Assumption 1
Remark 1

Assumption 1 implies sufficient actuation authority to always control the sign of x·2. The practical implication can be understood from the motor control problem. If x1,x2,f(x),andu are used to represent position, velocity, state-dependent load torque, and normalized motor torque respectively, then ap simply represents the minimum of the maximum achievable motor acceleration over the whole operating range x∈X, when the motor torque is set to its highest.

The primary objective is to devise a feedback controller u so that the state, x rapidly follows the reference, xr(t)=(r(t),r·(t))∈X while satisfying the state constraint. Due to the presence of state and input constraints, the class of reference considered here is assumed bounded.
Assumption 2

and |r··(t)|≤ar<ap,∀t.
Remark 2
To allow asymptotically converging tracking, the upperbounds of |r·(t)| and |r··(t)| are strictly less than the state constraint, x2max, and the achievable acceleration of the plant, ap respectively.

The tracking error is defined as z=(z1,z2):=x−xr(t)∈Z⊂ℜ2. The maximum and minimum values of z2 are determined by the state constraint and r·(t). They are given by z2max=x2max−r·(t),z2min=−x2max−r·(t) respectively.

As alluded to in the introduction, TO control in the absence of state constraints is bang–bang. The instance of switching can often be computed offline, stored as a function of states which is called the switching curve, and implemented using a lookup table [8]. This switching curve can be represented by a function ϕ(z2) which satisfies the following assumption.
Assumption 3
The following properties hold for all z∈Z.

list-item.p: There exist ar, z2δ≥0 such that |z2|+arξ(z2)>0 for all |z2|≥z2δ.

sec.p: Remark 3

Referring to Fig. 2 as an example, the switching curve crosses the origin, therefore Property 1 holds. Furthermore, Properties 2 and 3 hold because the curve passes through the second and fourth quadrant in the phase plane, and has negative gradient everywhere. Property 4 can be used to determine the limiting characteristics of the reference. For a particular ar, vr has to be chosen such that |x2max|−vr≥z2δ. This is to ensure the convergence of z1 to ϕ(z2) at the state boundary.

caption.p: Control magnitude transits gradually from +1 to –1 across the switching curve. The control law u1 operates in regions I, III, and IV, while u2 operates in region II

sec.p: In an ideal TO controller without state constraint, the control magnitude is always ±1. By referring to Fig. 2, when the state is on the left-hand side of the switching curve, the input is +1. However, if the state is on the right-hand side, the input is −1. These can be summarized as u=−sgn(s) when s=z1−ϕ(z2)≠0. If the state falls on the switching curve, that is s=0, the control becomes u=−sgn(z2) [8]. The control laws are summarized in Table 1. However, due to imperfections in switching devices, errors in modelling, and switching curve approximation, the state may cross along the switching curve at a high frequency, therefore causing chatter and leading to problems such as vibration and overheating of power electronics.

caption.p: Time-optimal control law without state constraint

sec.p: One approach to alleviate chatter is to define a high slope saturation function in the vicinity of the switching curve, where a gradual transition of control magnitude around the switching curve and the origin is introduced [10, 13, 15]. If the state is not on the constraint, the method in reference [15] can be adapted to non-linear plants and extended to handle reference tracking. The control law takes the form
where ks≥2,ssat>0, and z2sat>0 are tunable gains.

caption.p: Robust time-optimal control law for regions in Fig. 2

sec.p: In the state-constrained TO control problem, application of the TO control obtained for the unconstrained case may lead to state constraint violation. For system (3), when the states are on the constraint boundary, namely |x2|=x2max, Pontryagin’s maximum principle can be applied to show that the boundary is a part of the state-constrained time-optimal trajectory [7]. The TO control at this instance is the corresponding control that maintains the states at the constraint boundary, that is
The application of this control will eventually lead the states to the switching curve produced for the unconstrained time-optimal problem.
The regions in state space where the control laws (4) and (5) operate are listed in Table 2. The overall controller can be summarized as

sec.title: 2.2 Stability analysis
sec.p: In the following, the control law (6) is shown to asymptotically stabilize the system (3) to the origin.

We first show that any states in regions IV(a) and IV(b) (see Fig. 2) will converge towards z2=0, i.e. fall into either region I, III(a), or III(b). Furthermore, any states in region III(a) or III(b) will converge towards s=0, i.e. fall into either region I, II(a), or II(b). A trajectory starting in II(a) and II(b) converges towards the switching curve s=0. Finally, it is proved that the origin contained in region I is asymptotically stable.
Consider the system (3) with initial conditions that satisfy sz2>0 and s≠0. Suppose Assumptions 1 to 3 hold true. Under the control law (4), the trajectories converge to the z1-axis.
Define a Lyapunov candidate function V1=12(z2)2. Its time derivative is
where use is made of the fact that x·2=f(x)−bsgn(s) and Assumption 1. Furthermore, by applying Assumption 2
Since V·1<0 for all z2≠0, the trajectories converge to the z1-axis, that is z2=0. ■
Lemma 1 indicates that trajectories with initial condition in Region IV(a) or IV(b) move into Regions I, III(a), or III(b).
Consider the system (3) with initial conditions that satisfy sz2≤0 and |x2|<x2max. Suppose Assum-ptions 1 to 3 hold true, and let
Under the control law (4), |s(t)| will be strictly decreasing, and the set {|s|:|γ|≤1} is positively invariant.
First, it is shown that s=0 is contained in the set {s:|γ|≤1}. By substituting s=0 into (7), it is discovered that
When s(0)∈{s:|γ|>1}, the input is u=−sgn(s). Let the Lyapunov candidate function be V2=12s2. The time derivative is
where use is made of the fact that sz2≤0, and Assumptions 2 and 3. Therefore, |s(t)| is strictly decreasing and the set {s:|γ|≤1} is positively invariant. ■

Lemma 2 shows that any trajectories within regions III(a) or III(b) have strictly decreasing |s(t)|. However, the state trajectory may reach the state constraint before reaching the invariant set, which is region I. The following lemma shows that |s(t)| is strictly decreasing if the control law (5) is applied when the state is at the constraint.
Consider the system (3) with initial conditions that satisfy sz2≤0 and |x2|=x2max. Suppose Assumptions 1 to 3 hold true. Under the control law (5), |s(t)| will be strictly decreasing.

When the state is at the constraint, that is |x2|=x2max, and sx2≤0, the control law, u2 ensures that x·2=0. Choosing the Lyapunov candidate function as V3=12s2 and taking the time derivative results in
Therefore |s(t| is strictly decreasing and reaching the switching curve s=0. ■
The following lemma shows that the trajectories in Region I converge to the origin, yielding zero tracking error.
Consider the system (3) with initial conditions that satisfy s(0)∈{s:|γ|≤1} and x∈X−{x:|x2|=x2max,sx2<0}. Under the control law (4), the origin is asymptotically stable.
In vicinity of the origin, the control reduces to
The following closed-loop system shows that the origin is an equilibrium point
To check the asymptotic stability of the origin, let the Lyapunov candidate function be
By expanding the time derivative

Using Property 3 from Assumption 3, that is z2ϕ(z2)<0, it is obtained that V·4<0 for all z∈Z−{0}. Application of LaSalle’s invariant set theorem shows that the origin is asymptotically stable. ■
Collecting results from Lemma 1 to Lemma 4, the convergence analysis can be summarized as the following theorem.
Consider the system (3) and suppose Assumptions 1 to 3 hold true, the control law (6) asymptotically stabilizes the system (3) to the origin.

In the absence of modelling errors and disturbances, Theorem 5 indicates that for any initial conditions x∈X, the tracking error of the plant (11) converges to zero asymptotically under control (6). Moreover, the speed of the convergence is determined by the appropriate selection of the gains ks,ssat and z2sat. The assumption that no modelling errors are present is of course unrealistic, and motivates the following section which explicitly considers control in their presence.

sec.title: 2.3 Extension to modelling error
sec.p: In the face of modelling errors and input disturbance, the system (3) can be modified as
where |d(t)|≤δ∈ℜ is a bounded time-varying disturbance that satisfies the matching condition. Effects from both modelling errors and input disturbance can be encapsulated in d.
To accommodate the presence of a disturbance, Assumption 1 is modified as follows.

In the presence of disturbance, the feedback linearizing control (5) is not sufficient to maintain the state within the constraints. Therefore, a stabilizing component has to be added, and the control law is adapted as follows
where Δ>0 and kc>0.
Next, it is shown that by selecting appropriate set of Δ and ks, the adapted feedback linearizing–stabilizing controller (9) maintains the state within the state constraints.
Consider the system (8) and the control law (9), with initial conditions that satisfy sx2<0 and |x2|∈(x2max−Δ,x2max), where Δ>0. There exists kc>0 such that the region
is uniformly bounded.
Under the control law (9), the dynamics of x2 in (8) is given by
Furthermore, consider a new variable x^2=x2−(x2max−Δ2)sgn(x2) and a Lyapunov function V5=12(x^2)2. The time derivative of the Lyapunov function is
With c>(δ2)/(2kc2), a solution starting in the set {V5(x^2)≤c} will remain therein for all future time since V·5 is negative on the boundary V5=c. Hence, x2 is uniformly bounded in
In order to maintain the state within the state constraints, Δ and kc have to be chosen such that

Theorem 6 provides a remedy to avoid constraint violation by appropriate choices of Δ and ks, utilizing the worst-case estimate of the disturbance, δ. In order to achieve high performance, it is desirable to maintain x2 close to the state constraint. This can be done by selecting a small Δ and a large kc.

Furthermore, instead of asymptotic stability of the origin, the stability condition for the perturbed system (8) is relaxed to the stability of an uniform ultimate bound that contains the origin. Convergence results from region IV into region I follow directly using the methodology of the preceding section, while the ultimate boundedness result will be presented in the next theorem.
Consider the vicinity of the origin of the perturbed system (8), with initial conditions that satisfy s(0)∈{s:|γ|≤1}, x∈X−{x:|x2|=x2max,sx2<0}
and z2≤k2. Under the control law (4) the trajectories are uniformly ultimately bounded.

Therefore, by applying Lemma 9.2 in reference [19], the solutions are uniformly bounded by

Theorem 7 shows that the ultimate bound, β is proportional to the upper bound on the disturbance, δ. This result can be interpreted as a robustness property of the nominal system (3) with control law (6), as an arbitrarily small δ will result in a small ultimate bound, deviated from the origin. While the ultimate bound can be calculated qualitatively, it is usually found to be too conservative [19].

sec.title: 3.1 EMB model
sec.p: The prototype EMB used in this work is shown in Fig. 1. It is actuated by an electric motor that drives a planetary gear set. The rotational motion is converted to linear motion by a ball screw spindle connecting the planetary sun gear and the brake piston. This construction is typically shared among many prototype EMB designs such as references [2], [5], and [20].

For completeness, a control-oriented EMB model based on reference [4] is reproduced in the following. By considering a lumped inertia, stiffness and damping about the motor’s rotational axis, the torque equation is given by

where Fcl,J,Kt,iq,N,Tf,x1, and x2 represent brake clamp force, effective moment of inertia, motor constant, motor quadrature current, gear ratio, friction torque, motor angular position, and motor angular velocity respectively. Accordingly, in the context of the EMB system, f(.) and b in the right-hand side of (3) takes the following form
The input is normalized by the maximum motor quadrature current u=iqiqmax.
The lumped stiffness was experimentally found to be hyperelastic. With x1=0 defined as the contact position between the brake pad and rotor, the stiffness is phenomenologically modelled as
In order to capture Coulomb, viscous, and load-dependent sources of friction, the lumped non-linear friction torque is modelled as

where the friction model parameters D,C, and G are the viscous friction coefficient, load-independent Coulomb friction torque, and load-dependent friction torque coefficient respectively. The tanh function is used to approximate the Coulomb’s friction in order to ensure the continuous differentiability of friction torque with respect to the states [21]. A sufficiently large ε is chosen such that the friction model is close to the experimentally obtained measurements.

The EMB quadrature current input is constrained to avoid overheating the motor windings, while the maximum motor angular velocity is limited by the maximum voltage provided to the motor windings. The limits on current and velocity are |iq|≤iqmax and |x2|≤θ·max respectively. The operating range of EMB is between 0 to 30 kN and −x2max to x2maxrad/s, that is X={(x1,x2)∈ℜ2:Fcl(x1)∈[0,30000],|x2|≤x2max}. The experimentally identified EMB parameters are listed in Table 3.

sec.title: 3.2 EMB tracking controller
sec.p: A robust TO EMB tracking controller is presented using the design proposed in section 2. To this end, the following procedures will be executed.

list-item.p: Verify Assumption 1 to show that the EMB motor torque is greater than the torques produced by stiffness and friction. Then, find the minimum of the motor acceleration when u=±1 for the whole operating range, x∈X.
Compute the time-optimal switching curve offline and approximate it with a polynomial ϕ(z2).
For a given class of reference that satisfies Assumption 2, verify the characteristics of the approximated switching curve using properties in Assumption 3.
Synthesize the controller using the proposed structure (6).

sec.p: Step 1 (Verification of Assumption 1): To ensure that the EMB motor is powerful enough to change the direction of acceleration over the whole operating range, it is designed such that the available motor torque is always greater than the torques produced from stiffness and friction. The maximum magnitude of f(.) occurs when the clamp force is at its peak, Fcl(x1)=30 kN (or x1=43.7 rad), and the velocity is at the lower bound, x2=−300 rad/s2. Using the set of parameters provided in Table 3, ap=4302 rad/s2 is greater than zero, thus Assump-tion 1 is satisfied.

Step 2 (Computation of the time-optimal switching curve): The optimal-switching instance for the EMB system (11) is shown in Fig. 3. The curves are produced by setting u=±1 and integrating (11) backwards in time using a pair of fixed (r,r·). They correspond to the optimal switching instances for ramp reference with gradient r·, in order that (x1,x2) trajectory reaches (r,r·) in minimum time. By changing the coordinates to z, the switching curves are overlaid and plotted in Fig. 4. It can be seen that the switching curves are dissimilar for different r due to the plant non-linearities. The family of curves is approximated using a single switching curve and is designated z~1=ϕ(z2).

caption.p: Optimal switching instance for r(t)=0,10,…,50 rad for ramp tracking with r·(t)=0 (solid) and r·(t)=200 rad/s (dash-dotted); the state constraints are indicated by dashed lines
Optimal switching instance for r(t)=0,10,…,50 rad for ramp tracking with r·(t)=0 (solid) and r·(t)=200 rad/s (dash-dotted), plotted after the change of variable

sec.p: Step 3 (Verification of Assumption 3): The switching curve corresponds to the pair (r,r·)=(0,0) is chosen, and is approximated using a polynomial fit as shown in Fig. 5(a). The first three properties in Assumption 3 can be verified as follows. Since the curve intersects the origin, Property 1 is satisfied. Furthermore, Properties 2 and 3 are satisfied because the curve cuts through the second and fourth quadrants, and has negative gradient everywhere. We consider the class of reference with with bounded higher derivatives, where vr=270 rad/s and ar=4300 rad/s. Figure 5(b) shows that |z2|+arξ(z2)>0 for all 29≤|z2|≤650 rad/s, hence Property 4 is satisfied.

caption.p: Top: approximation of the switching curve using a fifth-order polynomial; bottom: for ar=4300 rad/s2, the first-order differentiation of the switching curve, ξ(z2) is larger than −|z2|/ar for all 29≤|z2|≤650 rad/s

sec.p: Step 4 (Controller synthesis): The EMB clamp force tracking controller is implemented as shown in Fig. 6. The clamp force reference and measurement are first converted to the motor position reference and measurement respectively, by using the inverse of (13) for Fcl∈[0,30] kN. Then, the time derivative of the reference r·(t) is estimated using the backward Euler differentiation scheme. Finally, the motor position and velocity references together with their measurements are fed into the control law (6). The controller gains ks,ssat,z2sat are tuned by small increments during implementation up to the limit of chatter.

caption.p: Block diagram of the EMB clamp force tracking control structure

sec.title: 4 Results and Discussion
sec.p: The experimental results presented in this section are performed using the static test rig of a prototype EMB shown in Fig. 7. The parameters of the EMB are experimentally identified and listed in Table 3. According to the operation specifications, the maximum clamp force of the brake is given as 30 kN and, and the maximum motor speed is given as 300 rad/s.

The computer communicates with the EMB through a controller area network (CAN) bus, where the clamp force reference is updated at 250 Hz. Measurements such as clamp force, motor speed, and motor quadrature current are obtained using the EMB onboard sensors and logged using Vector CANape.

The control law (6) is implemented to the onboard 16-bit microcontroller, where the clamp force control loop operates at 250 Hz. The proposed controller is benchmarked against the baseline PI controller proposed in reference [4], which represents the present industry practice.

caption.p: Experimental setup: the EMB (far right) communicates with the laptop PC (far left) through a CAN bus

sec.p: Clearance between the brake pads and the rotor is managed by a position controller. Once the pads and rotor are in contact, the clearance management controller is switched to the proposed controller, which is the main focus of this work.

The performance of an EMB is in part determined by how well it tracks a reference, which is important for demanding situations such as panic braking and during ABS operations. A series of tests are executed on standardized waveforms such as step, sinusoidal, and triangle. In order to reflect the importance of rapid reference tracking, the EMB performance for step responses is determined by the 10 per cent to 90 per cent rise time. To assess the performance of sinusoidal and triangle references tracking, the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) is used, which is defined as

where e,Fcl,r(mean) and T respectively represent the clamp force tracking error, the mean, and the period of the clamp force reference trajectories. In order to perform fair tests, the PI gains are tuned such that the available motor torque is fully utilized while avoiding integral windup due to input and state constraints, over the whole operating range.

A large step response of 20 kN is shown in Fig. 8. The proposed NTOC and the baseline PI controller have the same rising slope and similar rise time (see Table 4), indicating that the PI is well-tuned for a large manoeuvre. However, the PI is twice as slow at bringing the response to 0 kN, as the input switches from negative to positive too early. The NTOC responses are close to the ideal case apart from some overshoot during the falling phase, due to the control switching to the clearance management controller in the vicinity of the pads/rotor contact. Chatter which usually happens in the implementation of TO control does not occur here.

caption.p: Experimental result: step response for 20 kN
Tracking performance of baseline PI and NTOC for various trajectories; shorter rise time and smaller MAPE indicate better performance

sec.p: Although the proposed NTOC performed satisfactorily for a full brake apply, to ensure the consistency of step tracking performance within the range of operation, a smaller step manoeuvre of 2 kN is performed, and is shown in Fig. 9. The rising and falling responses of the NTOC are faster compared to the PI, suggesting that the fixed set of PI gains are too conservative for small step reference. As shown in the measured velocity and motor current, the NTOC fully utilizes the available motor torque to track the setpoint reference.

caption.p: Experimental result: step response for 2 kN

sec.p: Figure 10 presents the phase-portrait of step tracking responses. In order to show a range of operation, small and large manoeuvres are chosen, starting from 0 kN to 2 kN and 0 kN to 20 kN respectively. The NTOC demonstrates a longer acceleration period and achieves higher velocity for the 2 kN tracking. For the 20 kN tracking, the NTOC maintains velocity at (or slightly above) the state constraint for longer. The slight violation of the state constraint is due to errors from modelling and measurement, and could be remedied by imposing the feedback linearizing–stabilizing control law (9). However, the observed level of constraint violation is insignificant from an operational perspective. Overall, compared to the baseline PI, the time-optimal controller maintains the acceleration phase longer and begins the deceleration phase closer to the setpoint. The discrepancies in initial positions are due to the difficulty of obtaining an accurate 0 kN clamp force.

caption.p: Phase portraits for 2 kN and 20 kN setpoint tracking; the switching curve (solid), the boundary layer (dotted) and the state constraints (dashed) are shown

sec.p: To assess the tracking performance, a triangular profile between 0 to 20 kN with 2 s period was commanded. The ramp tracking trajectories of both controllers are compared in Fig. 11. For a 20 kN/s ramp, the NTOC demonstrates a fourfold improvement in MAPE as listed in Table 4.

caption.p: Experimental result: triangular reference tracking from 0 to 20 kN

sec.p: Figure 12 compares the sinusoidal reference tracking performance for both controllers. It is shown that the near time-optimal tracking controller has a larger bandwidth, and visually appears to track the reference significantly better than the baseline PI controller. There is a corresponding 50 per cent reduction in MAPE (Table 4), which would be even greater but for the presence of overshoot in the NTOC. This overshoot is likely due to the discretization of the controller and error in numerical differentiation of the reference.

caption.p: Experimental result: sinusoidal tracking of a 10 Hz reference with 15 per cent modulation about 2 kN

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: A state-constrained, robust near-time-optimal clamp force tracking controller for an automotive EMB is developed and proposed for use in electromechanical braking systems. First, the controller design for a generic second-order non-linear system with state constraints is presented, followed by the extension to a perturbed system with bounded, but potentially time-varying disturbance. The proposed controller is shown to be robustly stable, with the tracking error asymptotically converging to an uniform ultimate bound that contains the origin.

Design guidelines are then given to implement the proposed controller on a prototype EMB system. Once designed, the proposed controller is implemented on the prototype EMB. The proposed controller demonstrates superior performance over the baseline cascaded PI controller over a range of different experimental tests.

Further research directions include validating the EMB braking performance with the higher-level controllers such as ABS and electronic stability programme (ESP), and adapting these to fully utilize the performance of an EMB.

fn.p: This research was in part supported by the Australian Research Council through the grant FT100100538.
